National Association of Educational Broadcasters
630 Fifth Avenue

While listening for the second time to the superb NAEB series THE
JEFFERSONIAN HER IT ACE as broadcast here over WSUI, the conviction grew
in my mind that there should be a comparable series about another great
democrat, the late, Olympian Mr. Justice Braudels*
Since Louis D« Braudels, perhaps more than any other individual, had so
much to do with the expanded horizons of our present way of life, from
the standpoint of social, economic and industrial legislation, certainly
he deserves so much recognition? Considering his background and the
absorbing humanness and individuality of the man, the drama and conflict
of his life, there should be ample material for an inspiring and
informative series titled, perhaps, BRANDS IS? DISSENTING HtQPHET* As
lawyer and justice, LDB was first a determinedly free American and a
singularly conscientious citizen, yet nearly all that the average
supposedly well-educated, well-informed individual knows about him is
that he was a Jew and a Supreme Court Justice* In view of his monumental,
contribution to the American way of life, isn8t it about time something
was done to bring the facts homo to a thoughtful few at least?
May I suggest that Claude Rains would be an admirable choice to portray
Mr* Brandeis? Or Raymond Massey* And as technical adviser who could
possibly be a better choice than Dr* Alpheus Thomas Mason, currently
McCormick Professor of Jurisprudence at Princeton University? Dr* Iks on3 3
BRANDEIS? LAWYER AND JUDGE IN TEE MCDERN STATE and BRANDEIS? A FREE MAN°S
LIFE are authoritative, definitive —» and superb readingl They could, I
should think, form the point of departure for a superb radio series to
supplement and Implement THE JEFFEHSCMIAN HERITAGE*
Sincerely,
